Part 1: Forms of Energy

Student Guide


  1. Take all items out of Box 1 and explore for a few minutes.
  2. Identify the form of energy that each item uses or produces and record the information on Part I of your Explore Student Journal.
  3. Answer the questions.
  4. Put all objects back into Box 1.
  5. Repeat steps 1-4 for Box 2.

Student Journal


Answer

Item from Box 1Form(s) of Energy Observed
Hand WarmerThermal
BatteryElectrical
RulerSound
Glow StickLight
UV BeadsLight
Pop Rock CandySound
ScissorsMechanical
Question 1

How many forms of energy did each item use or produce?


Answer

Each item produced one form of energy.

Question 2

How can you tell the different forms of energy apart?


Answer

Through observation I can tell what form of energy is being produced. If it makes light, it is light energy. If the object makes a noise, then it is sound energy. If an object creates heat, then it is thermal energy. And if an object has moving parts to make it work, it has mechanical energy.

Question 3

How do the items in Box 2 compare to the items in Box 1?


Answer

The items in box two had more than one type of energy either produced or used, the items in box one only had one form of energy.

Question 4

Which item produces or uses the most forms of energy?


Answer

The TV and the cell phone each used or produced four types of energy.

Question 5

What other items could go in this box?


Answer

Dishwasher: electrical, heat, sound, mechanical
Stapler: mechanical and sound
Car: electrical, sound, and mechanical

Part II: Foldable

Student Guide


  1. Choose a card from Box 3. Each student group will have a different card.
  2. Write the name of your item beside the words, "My Item", on Part II of your Explore Student Journal.
  3. Then cut page 3 of your Explore Student Journal along the dotted line and fold on the bold line.
  4. Describe how your item uses or produces the form of energy under each flap.
  5. Glue your foldable to another sheet of paper or into your science notebook.

Student Journal


Fold on the bold line and cut along the dotted lines. Choose an item from Box 3. Write the name of your item beside the words, "My Item." Describe how your item uses or produces each form of energy under the flaps.

Answer
Part III: Find an Item

Student Guide


  1. Choose different items to represent each form of energy.
  2. On Part III of your Explore Student Journal, draw a picture of each item and describe what makes each different from the others in the way it uses or produces energy.
  3. Answer the questions in your Explore Student Journal.

Student Journal

Question 1

Choose an object to represent each form of energy. Draw a picture of the object. Describe what makes it different from the other objects in the way that it uses or produces energy.

Answer
Question 2

What are other examples of how we use energy in our daily lives?

Answer

We use energy in everything we do. Light energy provides us entertainment in watching TV and listening to the radio through sound energy. We use thermal energy in our heaters to keep us warm and electrical energy to provide us with power.

Question 3

Why is energy important?

Answer

Energy is important because most of our machines require and produce energy. Without energy we would not be able to communicate and move around.
